qas.question: What did most of the development of the mandolin revolve around?
Were premandolins quiet or loud instruments?
What are modern mandolins' strings made of?
What is the most common soundboard shape?
What are the sound holes covered with?

answers.text: bordered with decorative rosettes or purfling

qas.question: What is another term for the bottom of the mandolin?
What was louder than modern instruments?
How are teardrop-shaped holes covered or bordered?
How many courses of metal strings were pre-mandolin instruments strung with?
What did most of the development of the mandolin not revolve around?
Were postmandolins quiet or loud instruments?
What are ancient mandolins' strings made of?
What is the most uncommon soundboard shape?

plausible_answers.text: bordered with decorative rosettes or purfling

qas.question: What are the sound holes opened with?

context: Much of mandolin development revolved around the <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>soundboard<b5_0/> (the top)<b9_0/><a0_0/>. <b6_0>Pre-mandolin instruments<b6_0/> were <a1_0><b10_0>quiet<b10_0/> instruments<a1_0/>, strung with as many as six courses of gut strings, and were plucked with the fingers or with a quill. However, modern instruments are louder—using <a2_0><b8_0><b11_0>four<b8_0/> courses of metal strings<b11_0/>,<a2_0/> which exert more pressure than the gut strings. The modern soundboard is designed to withstand the pressure of metal strings that would break earlier instruments. The soundboard comes in many shapes—but <a3_0><b12_0>generally round or teardrop-shaped<b12_0/><a3_0/>, sometimes with scrolls or other projections. There is usually one or more sound holes in the soundboard, either round, oval, or shaped like a calligraphic F (f-hole). A round or oval sound hole may be covered or <a4_0><b13_0>bordered <b7_0>with decorative rosettes or purfling<b13_0/><b7_0/><a4_0/>.
